big_picture_notes: John presents a high‑theological narrative built as legal testimony so that readers may believe (20:31). The macro‑structure is framed by the Prologue (1:1–18) and Epilogue (21), with two central panels: the Book of Signs (1:19–12:50) and the Book of Glory (13:1–20:31). Literary glue includes irony/misunderstanding, double entendre (e.g., anōthen ‘again/from above’), I‑AM sayings, key vocabulary (life, light, know, witness, believe), and the recurring ‘hour’ motif. Signs are paired with discourses to reveal identity; the Passion shows glory in sovereign self‑giving.

stories.why_start_end_and_literary_glue: Poetic overture establishing Logos, life, light, witness, and incarnation; concludes with the unique Son making God known. Start (1:1) ‘In the beginning…’; End (1:18) ‘he has made him known.’ Glue: concentric structure centered on 1:14, repeated motifs (light/life/witness/glory).

scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: Genesis allusion stakes preexistence; light/darkness antithesis; creative agency repeated.

Word ‘tabernacled’ among us; grace in place of grace; Son makes Father known. Devices: glory motif, Moses vs grace/truth contrast.

stories.story_title: The Book of Signs: Public Revelation and Mounting Conflict
stories.why_start_end_and_literary_glue: Witness→sign→discourse pattern that escalates belief/unbelief, moving from Jordan/Cana to Jerusalem; ends with summary of Israel’s unbelief and Jesus’ final public words. Start (1:19): John’s testimony; End (12:50): final public declaration. Glue: sēmeia with explanatory dialogues, ‘the Jews’ as opposition shorthand, and festival settings.

Titles: Lamb of God/Son of God; eyewitness ‘I have seen’ grounds testimony.

Purification jars become wine; glory manifested, disciples believe; summary move to Capernaum.
Passover setting; body‑temple double entendre; post‑resurrection understanding noted.
Anōthen double sense; new birth by Spirit; Son lifted up for life; light judgment motif.

Healing triggers charge; equality with God intensifies conflict.
Authority to give life/judge; witnesses marshaled (John, works, Father, Scriptures, Moses).
Passover backdrop; abundance sign leads to king‑by‑force impulse.
‘It is I’ (egō eimi) epiphany; immediate arrival motif.

stories.why_start_end_and_literary_glue: Private love and instruction (13–17) lead into sovereign Passion/Resurrection (18–20); concludes with stated purpose (20:30–31). Start (13:1) before Passover; End (20:31) purpose statement. Glue: love/Paraclete motifs, ‘Truly, truly’ framing, and ‘hour’ fulfilled.

scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: Act‑then‑exhort: example for blessed doing; Peter misunderstanding clarified.
